text: we 're going to wrap up our live blog coverage for the day .
read the latest blog summary here .
we 've just published guardian washington bureau chief dan robert 's report on the hearing .

the top line : us police forces that use military equipment earmarked for counter-terrorism to handle public order disturbances instead could be forced to repay millions of dollars in grants , under a review revealed during the first congressional hearings into this summer 's riots in ferguson , missouri : the department of justice and the white house were already investigating whether to limit federal programs that have showered local law enforcement agencies with armoured vehicles and military-style equipment in recent years .

but the department of homeland security , one of three us agencies primarily responsible for providing the equipment , said it was now considering whether to demand that its grants be repaid if police are found to have broken a little-known rule prohibiting its use in riot suppression .

we have a range of remedies should [ the doj ] find non-compliance , including recoupment of funds , brian kamoie of the federal emergency management agency told kentucky senator rand paul during a hearing of the senate homeland security committee .

paul said he was horrified by the thoroughly un-american policing tactics seen in ferguson and demanded an immediate end to a similar pentagon program , called 1033 , that has provided 12,000 bayonets , 5,200 humvees and 617 mine-resistant armoured vehicles ( mraps ) to civilian forces across the us .
read the full piece here .

the parents and supporters of michael brown , the 18-year-old killed by a police officer on 9 august in ferguson , are renewing their calls for the officer 's immediate arrest , the ap reports : michael brown 's parents joined about 20 supporters tuesday morning at a news conference outside the ferguson police station .
a st. louis county grand jury is reviewing the case for possible criminal charges against officer darren wilson .
but family supporters said there is sufficient evidence to arrest and charge wilson now .
you do not need an indictment in order to arrest someone , said pastor carlton lee of flood christian church .
probable cause is sufficient enough to arrest civilians .
so it must be enough to arrest police .
tuesday marks one month since brown 's death .
we were horrified by seeing an unarmed man with his hands over his head being confronted by an armored personnel carrier , senator rand paul said .
confronting protesters with armoured personnel carriers is thoroughly un-american .
the washington post has video : posttv ( @ posttv ) .
@ senrandpaul says local police getting excess gear from the department of defense `` is crazy out of control ''
we wanted to resurface this bit of our coverage of the police response to the ferguson protests .

here 's what happened , according to the guardian 's jon swaine , reporting from the scene : a heavily armed , militarised police force fired teargas and rubber bullets to force hundreds of protesters out of the centre of a small missouri town on wednesday , as a crackdown on demonstrations over the killing of an unarmed 18-year-old intensified .

dozens of officers , some carrying assault rifles , advanced with a pair of armoured trucks on the young and predominantly african american crowd in fergsuon , after two glass bottles were thrown at their lines from a largely peaceful protest against the shooting of michael brown , who was black , by an officer from the city 's overwhelmingly white police department .
read the full piece here .

here 's a separate report on national trends in police tactics : the american civil liberties union has released the results of its new survey into the use of swat teams by police forces across the country .
it concludes that policing has become dangerously and unnecessarily militarized , literally so with equipment and strategies being imported directly from the us army .
the findings set up a striking and troubling paradox .

the obama administration is completing its withdrawal from afghanistan , and the us is on the verge of being free from war for the first time in more than a decade ; yet at the same time the hardware and tactics of the war zone are quietly proliferating at home .
the aclu 's report , war comes home , looks at 818 swat incidents that were carried out by more than 20 law enforcement agencies in 11 states .
the raids spanned the period from july 2010 to last october .

as our live coverage continues , here 's a summary of where things stand : at a committee hearing tuesday to investigate the militarisation of us police forces , senators warned that the transfer of military equipment to local forces lacked oversight .
the militarisation of police has gotten so far out of control , senator rand paul said .
the panel was convened after police in ferguson , missouri , responded with military force last month to protests over the 9 august shooting of unarmed teenager michael brown .

i think most americans were uncomfortable with a suburban street in st louis being transformed into a war zone complete with rubber bullets , tear gas and laser sights on assault weapons , senator claire mccaskill said .
billions of dollars ' worth of equipment has been transferred by the pentagon to local police since 1997 , officials testified .
the programs began with the drug war , officials said , but transfers have gradually included increasingly heavy equipment .
in the past three years , the pentagon has handed out 624 mine-resistant ambush-protected ( mrap ) armored vehicles .
the program excludes sniper rifles , grenade launchers , and apache helicopters , a pentagon official said .
but it does include bayonets , night-vision goggles , armored vehicles and combat knives .
36 % of the property transferred has never been used by the military , a senator said .

a state official appointed by the governor decides what to request , and the pentagon does not judge local needs for equipment , or provide training , or check the civil rights record of recipient departments , a defense official said .
ifrared camera from surplus program found boston marathon bombing suspect dzokhar tsarnaev , fema official testifies .
senator replies : tsarnaev was found because a guy went out to check his boat .
the second panel are reading their opening statements .

senator coburn pushes back on the primary example advanced so far of how pentagon equipment can help local police , that a forward-looking infrared camera on a state helicopter saw dzokhar tsarnaev inside the covered boat in a backyard in boston where he was found .
tsarnaev was found because a guy went out to check his boat , coburn says .
the militarisation of police has gotten so far out of control , and we 've allowed it to descend without a great protection of our civil liberties as well , paul says .

then paul brings up the story of an infant asleep in a playpen who was severely wounded when authorities looking for suspected drug dealer threw a flash grenade into his house , which turned out to be not the right house .

a georgia prosecutor has just announced a grand jury investigation in the case , the ap reports : a northeast georgia prosecutor says a grand jury will investigate a police raid that severely injured a baby when a flash grenade detonated in the child 's play pen .
district attorney brian rickman said tuesday that he will present results of an investigation into the botched raid to a grand jury on 29 september .
rickman told wsb-tv that the grand jury is expected to determine whether the raid in habersham county was handled appropriately , and it could return criminal charges if warranted .
no charges have been filed so far .
the boy was asleep in a play pen in late may when authorities looking for a suspected drug dealer threw a flash grenade into the house .
family members say the boy has undergone several extensive surgeries since the raid .
paul says cops do n't need bayonets but the pentagon has given out 12,000 of them to local police , paul says .
if you decided tomorrow that [ mraps ] are not appropriate for cities in the united states [ obama ] could decide tomorrow not to hand them out , paul says .
estevez says mraps have been used to protect police in shootouts .

text: senator rand paul : a lot of us were horrified by the images out of ferguson .
one of the fundamental things about america is dissent confronting protesters with armoured personnel carriers is thoroughly un-american .

guardian washington bureau chief dan roberts , at the hearing , tweets a displayed in the committee room of a mine-resistant ambush-protected ( mrap ) armored vehicle : dan roberts ( @ robertsdan ) ferguson hearing told police have more mrap vehicles than national guard .
73 in texas vs 6 for guard .
36 % brand new .
tammy baldwin , democrat from wisconsin , is next .
she asks estevez whether the pentagon considers whether local police departments have been investigated for a pattern civil rights deprivations before they get the gear .
consultation with the department of justice is one of the areas where we 're frankly lacking , estevez says .
senator ron johnson , republican of wisconsin , is up .
he asks what cops needed from the pentagon to combat the war on drugs .
estevez says police departments were outgunned by drug gangs .
but the surplus program continued to expand , johnson says , moving $ 5.1bn in equipment since 1997 .
do you know of many police departments that turn free things down ?
johnson asks estevez .
no , estevez does not .
mccaskill points out that texas police have received 73 mraps in three years , but the national guard in texas only has six .
estevez says there are 12,000 mraps to be distributed across the force structure , including the national guard .
the pentagon bought 24,000 total , he says .
and the military is keeping the best ones .
mccaskill says the guard does not want the mraps because they tear up the roads and have limited applicability .
mccaskill says one officer has 13 military grade assault weapons in their police department .
where 's the oversight ?
she asks .
estevez says he 'll look into it .
the rule of thumb is , one mrap for a police department that requests an mrap .
no more than one .
apparently there 's some waste in the pentagon budget .
of the 1033 [ surplus ] program , 36 % of the property issued is new , not used has never been used by the military , senator mccaskill says .
condition code a is like new , estevez says .
what in the world are we doing buying things that we 're not using ?
mccaskill says .
i guarantee you you 're buying again the stuff you 're giving away , she says .
challenged to name an incident apart from the boston marathon bombing in which pentagon equipment was used by local police , fema 's kamoie names the 2010 times square bombing attempt .
coburn says the program cost billions of dollars but officials can only point to two instances in which it 's been truly necessary .

documents.title: pentagon : 'it 's basically a common-sense decision '
text: estevez lists equipment the pentagon will not transfer to local police , including sniper rifles , grenade launchers , and apache helicopters .
it 's basically a common-sense decision inside the department , he says .
we used to provide body armour .
we no longer do that .
once body armor becomes excess , we can no longer guarantee its safety .
coburn , the republican from oklahoma , asks when the last time , in terms of true counter-terrorism , the pentagon military equipment was used .
coburn asks how the pentagon determines what can be transferred .
how do they decide that an mrap is appropriate for local police forces ?
estevez says an mrap is a truck .
it is not an offensive weapon .
it is stripped of all its electronic warfare capability .
it does not have a 50-caliber weapon .
carper asks about state-and-federal coordination to review how the military equipment is used by local police .
we need to do a better job at coordination , estevez says .
there 's probably a failure in coordination we do , when there 's missing equipment , coordinate .
but the pentagon could do better at coordinating how the equipment is used , estevez says .

documents.title: state appointees responsible for deciding what cops need
text: carper asks the first question .
do cops have the resources they need to meet the level of risk , he asks .
estevez says the pentagon equipment is useful to law enforcement , but it 's not really for our department to judge .
state coordinators , appointed by the governors , vet the needs of local departments and make requests of the federal government , estevez says .
the pentagon does n't assess whether they need it .
the final witness on the first panel is a department of justice official , karol mason , whose title is assistant attorney , office of justice programs .

as ojp 's assistant attorney general , i oversee an annual budget of more than $ 2 billion dedicated to supporting state , local , and tribal criminal justice agencies ; an array of juvenile justice programs ; a wide range of research , evaluation , and statistical efforts ; and comprehensive services for crime victims , she says : the recent events in ferguson show us that , as a nation , we still have more work to do .

the attorney general 's quick and decisive response to those events offers proof of the department 's firm resolve to ensure public safety and the fair administration of justice are in proper alignment .

ojp will continue to support these aims by providing america 's law enforcement community with the tools and resources it needs to uphold the law and earn the trust and respect of the citizens it serves .
next up : a fema official , brian e. kamoie .
he says the surplus program helped catch boston marathon bombing suspect dzokhar tsarnaev .
a forward-looking infrared camera on a state helicopter that found tsarnaev came from the pentagon , kamoie says .
he 's the assistant administrator for grant programs , federal emergency management agency .
estevez says 800 agencies in 49 states participate in the surplus program .
more than $ 3.1bn in property has been transferred since 1990 , he says .
the transfers include 460,000 piece of controlled property weaponry and related gear .
that count includes 92,000 small arms , 44,000 night vision goggles and 5,200 humvees or similar vehicles but not mraps , he says .
the pentagon does not provide cops with sniper rifles or uniforms , he says .
estevez gives examples of when police have used the gear to save lives .
he lists the response to superstorm sandy , in which cargo trucks and humvees were used to evacuate people from flooded areas , he says .
also on the list : a 2013 flood in louisiana and a texas shootout with gang members .
the department of defense does not push equipment on any police force , estevez says .
testifying first : a pentagon official , alan f. estevez .
his title is principal deputy under secretary of defense for acquisition , technology , and logistics
mccaskill concludes her statement and introduces the witnesses .
mccaskill says 36 % of the equipment moving from the pentagon to police is brand new .
why are we buying things in the department of defense merely to turn around and give it away ?
mccaskill asks .
mccaskill says much of the equipment is as mundane as office furniture .
but the donations include armored vehicles mraps built to withstand roadside bombs .
in last 3 years , the dod has handed out 624 mraps to police , including at least 14 departments with 10 officers or fewer .
local police have more mraps than the us national guard , mccaskill says .

text: claire mccaskill , the senior senator from missouri , where ferguson is located , speaks next .
i think most americans were uncomfortable with a suburban street in st louis being transformed into a war zone complete with rubber bullets , tear gas and laser sights on assault weapons .
i am confident that military police tactics are not compatible with the first amendment , she says .
next up : ranking member tom coburn , republican of oklahoma .
we 're on dangerous ground , of undermining the very principals that built the country , he says .
it 's hard to see a difference between the militarized police force we see in towns across america today , and the force that [ james ] madison had in mind i have some real heartburn , coburn says .
carper is talking about the flow of armored vests and vehicles and other gear from the pentagon to police .
he says committee staffers have reviewed the programs .
this review by congress is long overdue , he says .
these programs were established with a very good intention , carper says the question is whether our police receive what they truly need .
carper says there are instances in which police have been outgunned by criminals .
he cites the response to the 2013 boston marathon bombings as an instance in which police made appropriate use of military equipment .

good morning and welcome to our live blog coverage of the first government hearing on the militarization of american police forces since the ferguson protests and crackdown last month .
today 's hearing will feature witnesses involved in the government 's program to move aging or otherwise obsolete military gear from the pentagon to police departments across the country .

a second panel of witnesses to include a photographer who covered the ferguson protests , a representative of police unions and an naacp spokesperson will talk about the experience in the street of encounters between citizens and militarized police forces .
do cops need this equipment ?
when are they allowed to use it ?
who makes money from the sale of mililtary gear to police ?
and who decides who gets what ?
today 's hearing will be hosted by the senate committee on homeland security and governmental affairs .
guardian washington bureau chief dan roberts ( @ robertsdan ) will be reporting from the room .

on the question of who makes money , the guardian 's ed pilkington ( @ edpilkington ) traveled to oakland , california , yesterday for one of the country 's largest trade fairs for selling military gear to police forces .
ed writes : given the national soul-searching about militarized policing that ferguson inspired , you might expect to see a muted , self-reflective urban shield this year .
not so , judging from the hardware on display on the convention floor .

as you enter the vast exhibition space you are accosted by assault rifles , gas masks , helmets , tactical knives , robots , drones , night-vision devices and countless other references to the war zone .

the poster for the urban shield event itself shows a police officer from oakland 's local alameda sheriff 's department wearing a helmet and goggles and pointing an assault rifle directly out at the viewer .
he crouches above a clock that has stopped symbolically at 9:11 , alongside the words critical training 4 critical times .
